title: noun
description: noun A noun names a person, animal, place, thing, quality, idea, activity, or feeling. A noun can be singular, plural, or possessive.

title: pronoun
description: pronoun is a word that takes the place of a noun, like "I," "you," or "they."

title: verb
description: A verb shows action and can be a main verb (such as "run" or "sit") or a helping verb (such as "were" or "has"). Verbs also indicate tense and sometimes change their form to show past, present, or future tense. You'll also find linking verbs, which link the subject to the rest of the sentence (such as "appear" and "seem")

title: adjective
description: adjective modifies a noun or a pronoun. Adjectives usually, although not always, come before the noun they're modifying. It adds meaning by telling which one or what kind, or describing it in other ways.

title: adverb
description: adverb modifies a verb and shares more information about it, including how much, when, where, why, or how.

title: preposition
description: preposition demonstrates a relationship between nouns or pronouns. They're often used with a noun to indicate location, like "beside," "in," or "on." It can also show time, direction, motion, manner, reason, or possession. Note that prepositions must always be followed by a noun or pronoun.

title: conjunction
description: Conjunctions connect two words, phrases, or clauses. Common conjunctions include "and," "but," and "or."

title: determiners
description: determiners are words placed in front of a noun to make it clear what the noun refers to.
